area_name: Warm up Wall, Frances B. Petersen Preserve

content.description: Start low in the dirty crack and make your way up the crack to the top left of the tree.
content.location: leftmost significant crack on warm up wall, sit start

content.description: JayV & I cleaned this off and JayV went back for the send! Start as low as you can on the left arete of the warm up wall. Ride the arete right to the high point of the warm up wall. Feet are pretty bad, spans are pretty reachy, rock is sharp, and you gotta fight the urge to topout at a couple spots.
content.location: Left arete of warm up wall

content.description: Climb the crack rightwards to the top of the wall, good hands, jams, and feet the whole way.
content.location: Center of wall in the wide right angling crack

content.description: Climb the crimpers to the top of the wall where the right crack meets at the lip
content.location: On the face right of the right angling crack

content.description: Traverse the edge of the wall starting as low as possible on the right side arching through some cool knobs and slaps to the top of the wall.
Cool start jugs, climb the ledge/face/arete to the point (or dino to the point for some fun), top out above point, mind the sharp crystals.
content.location: To the right of crack with the tree.

content.description: Climb the slopes and edges just in from the outer edge, join the lip at the top.
content.location: just left of illegal dumping start on the sloper and good feet.

content.description: Climb the crack that is slowly expanding/crumbling from tree roots. Can have direct finish or bail left
content.location: second crack in from climber's left

pathTokens: Warm up Wall, Frances B. Petersen Preserve

content.description: Adjacent to the (Mary Edwards) Diamond ledge preserve exists the Frances B. Petersen Preserve, another Granby Land Trust property. This preserve is just off old Broad hill road and has the same rock type as diamond ledge main face, with varying quality. There are some boulders on this lot, the most significant of which is the ~14ft tall warm up wall. This wall has morning-early afternoon sun and several easy problems with a flat landing, perfect for beginner boulderers. If you climb here or at diamond ledges employ leave no trace ethics & considering donating to the Granby Land Trust (www.granbylandtrust.org) to help preserve these areas.
